body: Tentatively slated for 5.6 M1 for _team discussion_

Brainstorming:

- Something like JUnit 4's `RuleChain` (discussed with @sormuras) -- though that requires potentially copying a lot of the internal logic of the `JupiterTestEngine`.
- Something like `@javax.annotation.Priority` combined with `@Order`.

Um, doesn't Jupiter already support this feature?

https://junit.org/junit5/docs/current/user-guide/#extensions-registration-programmatic

> **Extension Registration Order**
> By default, extensions registered programmatically via `@RegisterExtension` will be ordered using an algorithm that is deterministic but intentionally nonobvious. This ensures that subsequent runs of a test suite execute extensions in the same order, thereby allowing for repeatable builds. However, there are times when extensions need to be registered in an explicit order. To achieve that, annotate each `@RegisterExtension` field with `@Order`. Any `@RegisterExtension` field not annotated with `@Order` will appear at the end of the sorted list.
Yes, it works with extensions whose execution order is not reversed. However to make AfterEachCallback extension executed first all others should also be annotated with `@Order`.

> Any `@RegisterExtension` field not annotated with `@Order` will appear at the end of the sorted list.

Meaning, all not annotated extensions are executed last in the "before" phase and also last in the "after" phase?

Like this? `o1, o2, x, y, z, test(), o2, o1, z, y, x`

In the "after" phase all **not** annotated extensions are executed **before** the annotated ones. Setting extension `@Order(1)`  in the "after" phase makes extension execute **last** instead of being **first**. So there is no way to make an "after" phase extension be executed first, without annotating all others "after" extensions with `@Order`.

Brainstorming # 2:

- Use `Integer.MAX_VALUE - 1` as the default order. Then `Integer.MAX_VALUE` could be declared by users to signal the very last registration order, which would be the first order when reversed.
- Otherwise, I think using `@Priority` would be a viable alternative.

Thank you. The first option works, event though it's not very convenient to annotate all extensions with `@Order`.
However, to my shame, I haven't figured out how to use `@Priority` with `@Order`. Would you mind giving the example?

> Thank you. The first option works, event though it's not very convenient to annotate all extensions with `@Order`.

My point was that, if we made that change, users would no longer have to declare `@Order` on all extension fields.

> However, to my shame, I haven't figured out how to use `@Priority` with `@Order`. Would you mind giving the example?

We do not yet support `@Priority`. The "brainstorming" is about things that we could decide to do.

rename.to: Support first/last order for extensions registered via @RegisterExtension

body: New brainstorming idea: Change the default to `Integer.MAX_VALUE / 2` and introduce a `DEFAULT` constant so that the above use case can be written as `@Order(DEFAULT + 1)`.
**Team Decision:** Let's go with the latest proposal above.

issue.title: Support for JUnit 5.4 - test method ordering

repository.name: spring-cloud-contract
repository.description: Support for Consumer Driven Contracts in Spring

issue.body:
re: https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/48#issuecomment-463456291 (and following comment)

Using JUnit5 with Spring Cloud Contract (SCC), I noticed this behavior in 2.1.0:
- Naming a contract (YAML) with a numeric prefix triggers code generation failure, with the message "Not implemented yet in JUnit5 - https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/48"

I tracked it down to https://github.com/spring-cloud/spring-cloud-contract/blob/8ce80e6e7fc0267a9cba1679bdf20f42ce875741/spring-cloud-contract-verifier/src/main/groovy/org/springframework/cloud/contract/verifier/config/framework/JUnit5Definition.groovy#L63.

Initially I posted to the issue link in the message, but find it's really a SCC issue, not a JUnit one.

JUnit 5.4 provides an experimental annotation, `@TestMethodOrder`, with 3 interesting policies:
- Run tests in alphanumeric order based on generated method name
- Run tests in random order
- Run tests in user-specified order using the `@Order` annotation on each test method

Is there any mechanism for YAML format whereby I can ask for annotations on the SCC-generated methods, or possibly on the generated test class?

`@TestMethodOrder` is marked `@Inherited`, so I'm trying out placing it on my test base class, but am encountering issues (Spring framework is behaving oddly, having problems with classpath and loading the context.)

My sample project is http://github.com/binkley/basilisk
